Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Model-based Foundations of Collective Systems Design Theory

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) grant supports fundamental research to create and validate models of collaboration in engineering systems design. Engineering systems encompass a broad class of real-world systems which go beyond traditional boundaries of engineered artifacts to interact with and contribute to key societal functions. Performance is partially driven by technical capabilities but also by social constructs including policies, markets, incentives, and objectives. Pursuing shared objectives such as sustainability or security requires collective efforts among a diverse set of actors representing multiple firms, organizations, and agencies with potentially conflicting individual objectives. Existing systems engineering approaches do not align well with the decentralized nature and barriers to information exchange inherent to engineering systems. Consequently, engineering systems development often results in systems that are more costly than anticipated, take longer to develop than anticipated, and fail to meet desired levels of performance. This project contributes a mathematical framework and preliminary experimental results to understand how collaborative, systems-based approaches can achieve shared objectives in the design of engineering systems. This project will yield basic results that are applicable to many kinds of engineering systems, including but not limited to transportation systems, energy systems and defense systems.

The objective of this project is to understand how the structure of a design problem and interactions among design actors can facilitate or inhibit collective action. A mathematical framework characterizes a multi-actor system design problem as a set of design decisions and value flows contributing to strategic behavior. It builds on a game-theoretic model of system design as a two-part decision: lower-level decisions choose designs to maximize value in a fixed context and higher-level decisions choose a collective strategy to maximize value under interactive effects. This project considers simplified two-player design problems structured to represent four canonical coordination games. A human subjects experiment asks role-players to complete a series of pair design problems to maximize individual objectives. Results analyze how the problem structure and observed interactions influence the balance between cooperative versus non-cooperative strategies while controlling for demographic and personality factors believed to affect individual and collective performance. Understanding how technical and organizational factors influence designer behaviors will contribute to improved mechanisms and incentives to achieve desired collective results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to understand how the structure of strategic interactions among participating design actors influences adoption of joint system concepts. Intellectual merit results of this project refined a mathematical framework to model engineering design as a bi-level decision problem and provided experimental validation of key concepts by comparing observed bi-level decisions in a human study to those predicted by game theory. Broader impact results of this project contributed open-source software applications used in undergraduate and graduate education, provided training for a doctoral student with a dissertation based on this project, and seeded new investigations to study strategic relationships between government and commercial actors for Earth science space systems.

The bi-level modeling framework distinguishes between lower-level operational decisions and upper-level strategic decisions. Lower-level decisions follow traditional engineering design principles to optimize for a design actor's individual preference within a fixed strategic context. Upper-level decisions draw on game theory to vary the strategic design context as an interactive decision-making process with other design actors. Upper-level relationships among actors are characterized by two dimensions (S: sucker's payoff and T: temptation to defect), yielding four dynamical domains (cooperation, defection, bistability, or coexistence). Figure 1 shows the normative strategy (D: defect, C: cooperate) in each dynamical domain based on equilibrium selection theory for single-shot games.

Project results identified examples of all four strategy dynamics in existing engineering literature. Engineering design with centralized objectives exhibits cooperation dynamics which align decisions to desirable outcomes. Free-riding on team projects produces defection dynamics (i.e., a Prisoner's Dilemma game) which generate conflict between individual and collective objectives. System-of-systems engineering problems exhibit bistability dynamics (i.e., a Stag Hunt game) where there is tension between solutions with two levels of risk and efficiency. Finally, leader-follower dilemmas in engineering management exhibit coexistence dynamics (i.e., a Chicken game) where two actors struggle for control.

The central experiment in this project studied how strategy dynamics influence lower- and upper-level decision-making for human design actors. The experimental design assigned a series of parameter design tasks to a pair of designers with four pre-determined strategy dynamics on the S-T plane illustrated in Figure 2. Each design actor controls one lower-level decision with nine alternatives and one upper-level decision to either defect or cooperate. Results show design actors can identify high-quality lower-level decisions for all strategy dynamics but deviate from economic rationality for upper-level decisions in some cases. In alignment with normative game theory, cooperation dynamics exhibit strong cooperation and coexistence dynamics yields high levels of heterogeneous strategies. In slight contrast to normative game theory but in agreement with broader behavioral research findings, bistability and defection dynamics show stronger-than-expected levels of cooperation. Results provide initial evidence that the temptation to defect (T) factor is more significant than sucker's payoff (S) in bi-level design problems which may guide future efforts to mitigate the effect of unfavorable strategy dynamics.

Results from this project contributed to two experimental software applications which are publicly available on GitHub. First, the software used for the experimental tasks provides a resource for other researchers to conduct computational or human studies of bi-level decision problems. Second, a lightweight software application to study the bistability dynamic frames a discussion of the Stag Hunt game which has been deployed in multiple research seminars and classroom lectures for undergraduate- and graduate-level education. To date, results from this project have contributed to three conference papers, one journal article, the central thesis of one doctoral dissertation, and follow-on research in a CAREER award. Results from this project have also contributed to ongoing research for future Earth science space systems which envision greater coupling across organizational boundaries. Future applications of the results of this project will seek to frame space systems design as a bi-level decision problem to characterize the strategy dynamics and identify mechanisms or incentives that may stabilize cooperative behaviors.
